docs.lead_paragraph: The debate over the adequacy of Government financing for AIDS research intensified in Congress today as a top public health official said he had recommended an additional $70 million increase next year and a Harvard scientist said even that would not be enough to cope with a ''mounting disaster.'' Dr. James O. Mason, Acting Assistant Secretary for Health in the Department of Health and Human Services, told a Senate committee he had recommended that Federal spending for research on acquired immune deficiency syndrome be increased by $70 million above the Reagan Administration's $126 million request for the fiscal year 1986. That request would increase spending by about $17 million over the current fiscal year, which ends Sept. 30. Dr. Mason said the request for the $70 million more, which would be used primarily to support clinical tests of new drugs to combat the lethal disease, had been forwarded to the Office of Management and Budget for review and possible submission to Congress.

headline.main: TOP HEALTH OFFICIAL AND EXPERT SEEK GREATER RISE IN AIDS MONEY

docs.lead_paragraph: Thousands of people who have drug, alcohol or psychological problems are involved in handling the nation's nuclear weapons, a Stanford University professor said today. The professor, Dr. Herbert L. Abrams, a radiologist at Stanford's Center for International Security and Arms Control, said Defense Department records showed that an average of more than 5,000 people a year handling nuclear weapons were removed from their duties in the past 10 years, despite a screening process to weed out unreliable personnel. Mr. Abrams said that unreliable personnel could be dangerous in times of crisis ''when tensions are high and time for decision-making short.'' A Pentagon spokesman, informed of Dr. Abrams's comments, said, ''We have very stringent control over these weapons.'' The spokesman, who asked that his name be withheld, said the removal of so many people showed that screening, which he called a continual process, was effective.
